questions.question: Do any of your family members share the same types of difficulties as your child?
Does your child have trouble working with the individual sounds in words (sometimes called ‘phonological awareness’)?
Does your child find it hard to follow instructions that are given to them?
Does your child read in a slow or choppy way, making it harder to understand what they read?
Does your child find it difficult to work out new or tricky words when reading?
Does your child have ongoing and noticeable trouble with spelling?
Does your child find it hard to think of the right words to say or write?
Does your child often say words incorrectly, such as mixing up sounds within the word?
Does your child struggle with short-term or ‘working’ memory (for example, holding information in mind while doing a task)?
Does your child take longer than most children to finish written work?
Does your child find it difficult to copy words or sentences from the board at school?
Does your child seem to have ‘good days’ and ‘bad days’ with their learning, without a clear reason?
Does your child often show signs of low self-esteem, such as lacking confidence in their abilities?
Does your child’s writing seem weaker than their speaking skills would suggest?
Does your child need extra time to answer questions out loud?
Does your child appear to dislike or avoid reading for pleasure?
Does your child seem physically clumsy or uncoordinated compared to others?
Does your child find hopping or skipping more difficult than other children their age?
Do any of your family members share the same sorts of challenges your child faces?
Did your child reach milestones (like crawling or walking) later than most children?
Does your child still struggle with dressing themselves (for example, managing buttons or zips)?
Does your child often bump into objects or people by accident?
Does your child have difficulty running, hopping, jumping, or riding a bike?
Does your child struggle with handwriting on a regular basis?
Does your child find it hard to use scissors, cutlery, or other small tools?
Does your child seem unaware of possible dangers around them, like not noticing moving cars?
Does your child often fail to finish their classwork on time?
Does your child have trouble with ball games or sports because of poor coordination?
Does your child find it difficult to follow multi-step instructions?
Does your child have poor posture (for example, slouching) or very flexible joints (sometimes called hypermobility)?
Does your child get tired (lack stamina) more quickly than other children?
Is your child’s performance sometimes very inconsistent, changing from day to day?
Does your child struggle to pay attention to what they’re doing?
Was your child’s speech and language development slower than usual?
Does your child have strong reactions to certain sounds, textures, or other sensory experiences?
Does your child need extra time to understand or respond to information?
Do any of your family members show similar difficulties to what your child experiences?
Does your child sometimes act like they are not listening when you speak to them directly?
Does your child frequently fail to finish tasks or chores after being told what to do?
Does your child find it difficult to plan tasks or figure out how to start them?
Is your child easily distracted by what’s going on around them?
Does your child often forget things they need to do each day (for example, homework or personal items)?
Does your child lose things and appear disorganised (for example, always misplacing school supplies)?
Does your child find it hard to remain seated when it’s expected?
Does your child call out answers or speak before you finish asking a question?
Does your child find it difficult to engage in quiet, calm activities?
Does your child struggle to control their emotions, perhaps getting upset easily?
Does your child seem to be constantly on the go, as though they can’t sit still?
Does your child talk very quickly or seem unable to stop talking?
Does your child often interrupt others or jump into conversations at the wrong time?
Does your child sometimes seem to be daydreaming or ‘in their own world’?
Does your child find it difficult to wait for their turn in games or conversations?
Does your child struggle to stay focused on tasks they find less interesting?
Does your child fail to notice when a situation might be risky or dangerous?
Do any of your family members share similar challenges to your child?
Does your child respond when others talk to them but rarely start conversations on their own?
Does your child find it hard to understand jokes or phrases that aren’t meant to be taken literally (like “it’s raining cats and dogs”)?
Does your child struggle to read other people’s body language or social cues?
Does your child get too close to others without noticing personal space?
Does your child say things that are true but might seem rude or inappropriate in certain situations?
Does your child make eye contact in ways that seem unusual, for example staring or avoiding it altogether?
Does your child often appear overactive or uncooperative when asked to take part in group activities?
Does your child find it difficult to keep friends or make new ones?
Is your child especially bothered by certain sounds (like loud noises) or textures (like itchy clothes)?
Does your child get upset or anxious when their usual routine changes?
Does your child find it hard to use skills they learned in one setting when they’re in a new setting?
Does your child struggle to understand the meaning of what they read, even if they can read the words correctly?
Does your child speak in a way that sounds unusual (for example, using a very flat or very sing-song voice)?
Does your child like to do the same task or activity over and over, or follow certain rituals in a strict way?
Does your child move in an unusual way, such as flapping their hands or spinning around frequently?
Does your child become especially anxious or show more extreme behaviours than usual in unfamiliar situations?
Does your child fail to recognise when something might be dangerous?
Do any of your family members share your child’s difficulties with numbers or maths?
Does your child struggle to count in the correct order (for example, skipping numbers)?
Does your child mix up the order of digits in a number (for example, writing 29 instead of 92)?
Does your child find it hard to remember how numbers look or how to write them?
Does your child struggle to understand maths symbols (for example, +, −, ×, ÷)?
Does your child find it difficult to understand ideas about space or direction (like knowing left from right)?
Does your child take a long time to finish maths work?
Does your child have trouble making sensible guesses or estimates in maths (for example, estimating the number of objects)?
Does your child struggle to plan out how to solve maths tasks or problems?
Does your child find it hard to remember basic maths facts (for example, 2 + 2 = 4)?
Does your child seem very anxious or worried whenever they do maths?
Does your child have trouble knowing where they are in a space or which direction to go in?
Does your child mix up numbers that look alike (like 6 and 9)?
Does your child seem unsure about place value (for example, what the ‘2’ in ‘20’ means)?
Does your child struggle to recognise or remember common shapes (like triangles or squares)?
Does your child find it hard to count backwards (for example, counting down from 10)?
Does your child have difficulty reading a clock with hands (analogue) or understanding time?
Does your child find it difficult to quickly see how many items are in a small group without counting them one by one?
Do any of your family members share the same types of language or communication challenges as your child?
Does your child seem to listen but still not understand what was said?
Does your child pause or struggle to respond when you give them an instruction or ask a question?
Does your child only seem to understand things that are happening right now, and struggle with ideas about past or future events?
Does your child find it difficult to understand phrases that aren’t literal (like ‘pull your socks up’) or words that have more than one meaning?
Does your child sometimes only follow the first or last part of an instruction and miss out the rest?
Does your child have trouble learning and using new words in everyday conversation?
Does your child know a word but forget it, or mix it up with a word that sounds similar?
Does your child find it hard to form longer sentences that make sense?
Does your child’s speech often sound muddled, with words or ideas getting mixed up?
Does your child pause a lot or restart their sentences frequently when they talk?
Does your child find it difficult to understand or create stories with a clear beginning, middle, and end?
Does your child struggle to join in games or activities that rely on following spoken directions?
Does your child find it challenging to join in and keep up with conversations in a group?
Have you noticed your child getting frustrated and behaving badly because they can’t communicate as they would like to?
Does your child have reading or writing difficulties that seem linked to their language challenges?
Is your child often good at practical, hands-on tasks, even if they struggle with language?
